text:
“Hi, my name is
Cate Shortland,

and I am the director
of ‘Black Widow.’"

So this scene is
between Natasha,

played by Scarlett
Johansson, and Yelena,

played by Florence Pugh, and
they haven’t seen each other
in 20 years.”
“Ah!”

“Well the first thing we
did was speak to Rob Inch,

who was choreographing
the fight,

about what the
fight was about.

And it was about two
girls coming back together

as strangers, but
they’re also family,
and they’re also killers.

So it has all these
different levels to it,
which he was able to get.

And we were really
lucky, because Florence

had a history in
dance, and Scarlett

had been privy to all these
years of choreography.

So we could actually shoot
main unit a lot of this

fight, which was
the joy of it,

because we’ve got our
two actors in the frame
and not stunt performers.

The choreography uses elements
within the set design,
such as curtains.

We used a stapler,
a knife, the dust,

everything’s kicking
up around them,

and we shot purposefully
through doorways.

And I didn’t want the
camera on eye-level.

I wanted to totally
take it off eye-level,

so we are above
them, below them,

and it has this very
organic, messy feel.

And yet, they’re in
this really ornate,
crumbling eggshell blue room.

So we’ve got this Nan Goldin
inspired apartment building.”

“I’m not here trying
to be your friend,

but you need to tell
me what that is.”

“So the scene in the bedroom
is really like two teenage

girls arguing over their
clothes, or something.

And again, this is kind
of pushing the familial

relationship and the
history of the characters.”

“Why don’t you take it to
one of your super scientist
friends?
They can explain it to you.
Tony Stark, maybe?”
“Oh.

We’re not really
talking right now, so--”
“Great, perfect timing.

Where’s an Avenger
when you need one?”
